Situation1: A serious situation has come up in the family, and the grandmother's presence is needed.
Situation2: They quietly repeat a short mantra during their day without following the full ritual.
Story: I sat in the living room, the voices of my grandchildren echoing from the kitchen. My daughter called out, her voice tight with worry—my presence was needed. Something serious had happened, and as the grandmother, I was expected to comfort, to guide, to be the steady hand in the storm. Yet, as I stood, I felt the weight of another expectation pressing on me. As a Hindu, my daily rituals are not just habits; they are my anchor, my way of connecting with the divine. Today, I had only managed to quietly repeat a short mantra, unable to perform the full puja with incense and offerings. Guilt gnawed at me. My family needed me, but so did my faith. I could feel the pull from both sides, each demanding my time, my heart. I lingered in the hallway, torn between the sacred and the familial, unsure which path to take next.
